title: The story is finally coming together
body:
And I'm _very_ interested in seeing what it's going to look like when it's complete.

With this recent lore update we've managed to link Vladimir, Veigar and Nocturne to the major factions of the world, and strengthened each faction's involvement in the business of the others.

Vladimir is linked to the Darkin (and, by extension, Shurima), the Shadow Isles (though Mordekaiser and his garden) and Noxus. Veigar is linked to Noxus and Bandle City. Nocturne is linked to both the spirit world and shadow magic, which is currently kept in Ionia and was used to cause destruction during the Rune Wars.

The Rune Wars came after the Great Darkin War. The Darkin were created by Targon, who are fighting the threat of Icathia and the Freljord, where the Void stirs from its slumber. Mordekaiser wants his fortress back, and is rallying large portions of the Shadow Isles under his banner. LeBlanc is pulling the strings in numerous countries for an unknown purpose.

Ionia and Shurima, both linked to Targon, and, through it, the Freljord, are linked to Noxus, which Demacia is linked to. Demacia is seemingly beset by demons (two of which are brought forth into the world during the Rune Wars), and houses the world runes, which Ryze is protecting. Ryze is linked to Mordekaiser and LeBlanc (who both come from the Noxii tribes), the Shadow Isles (through Tyrus), and several parts of the world thanks to the world runes. Even Bilgewater is linked to the main storyline through Tahm Kench (link to demons and the Rune Wars), Fizz (link to Bandle City), Nagakabouros (link to the spirit world), the Shadow Isles and Noxus.

That's all not to mention the vastayashai'rei, shadow magic and Syndra, which are kept in Ionia ("the First Lands"), Piltover and Zaun, and the "great darkness" that Swain foresees.
---
The puzzle is coming together. Everything is linked to something else. Even the smallest character's actions can have major reprecussions on the future of the universe. The Watchers are waking up. Perhaps there's something darker still waiting from beyond them?

That's... just incorrect. It's not _living_ things they care about. They want to destroy all _matter._ Many of the Voidlings like to eat and/or incorporate living things into themselves, but the Watchers simply want to get rid of the existence that contrasts their lack thereof. The Voidlings are simply one of their means to that eventual end.

Veigar isn't related to Noxus. He was in his old lore, but not in his new lore. In his new lore, he's related to Mordekaiser and the Immortal Bastion, but he escaped Mordekaiser's crumbling empire once Mordekaiser was defeated, which gives him no relation to Noxus, as the city state didn't exist when Veigar fled from captivity.

Mordekaiser is the empire's past and future. When Mordekaiser comes to reclaim the Immortal Bastion, Veigar is going to have to stand against him (an evil sorcerer and his former master). That's his link to Noxus.

No, that is his link to Mordekaiser. Veigar has no horses in the race in regards to Noxus. Noxus is merely the city that spawned around his former prison after Mordekaiser's death, and you also cannot claim that Veigar will so willingly present himself back to the monster that tortured him for lord knows how many years. Even if he does, Veigar will be dealing with Mordekaiser on behalf of himself, with no affiliation or relations to Noxus.

What you're claiming would be like saying someone would have links to a Wal-Mart that was built over a former plot of land their childhood home was on.

You're misunderstanding something.

1. **Veigar is not affiliated with Noxus.** But he is part of the grander scheme of things. In the overarching Noxian storyline, Veigar played a part as Mordekaiser's servant, and will likely play a part when Mordekaiser is ready to take his fortress back.

2. **Veigar is Mordekaiser's enemy.** I haven't stated otherwise. Veigar is clearly opposed to tyrants and evil sorcerers, and won't ally with Mordekaiser should he return; rather, he will directly oppose him.

Veigar doesn't oppose tyrants and evil sorcerers intentionally. Veigar wants power, and he wants more magic at his disposal, therefore, he is conquering those who are in power in areas, but those people also happen to be tyrants and evil sorcerers. I don't think he'd discriminate if an area was controlled by a good mage - he'd still try to conquer them and take their powers for himself.
And obviously, he wouldn't ally with Mordekaiser. But you're assuming he would actively try to directly oppose him, which we've been given no indication of. Mordekaiser kept Veigar in captivity for years, if not decades or centuries, to the point where he corrupted a Yordle. That's no small feat, and I cannot imagine that Veigar would actively seek to present himself to his captor again. I think Veigar would accrue power very far away from Mordekaiser, and only deal with him if Mordekaiser was on his doorstep. I don't think Veigar is altruistic enough to hear that "Hey Morde is alive again" and then rush off to try to kill him.
